newsitem.title: GERMANY: Creditors to get $165 million from Schneider.
newsitem.headline: Creditors to get $165 million from Schneider.

text.p: Creditors of disgraced German real estate tycoon Juergen Schneider have moved closer to recovering a portion of funds owed them, Christoph Rueckel, Schneider's attorney said on Wednesday.

Rueckel said that 245 million marks ($165 million) seized from Schneider in Switzerland should shortly be handed over to a trustee who is charged with repaying funds to creditors of the real estate investor when he went bankrupt and fled Germany in 1994.

A Swiss judge involved in the fund seizure confirmed the attorney's statement, adding that transfer of the funds to a trustee will not take place until the middle of next week at the earliest to allow for an objection period to expire.
Rueckel said Schneider and his wife Claudia had nothing against the fund transfer and hoped the creditors would get the money soon.
"Dr. Schneider will not use any means of legal address to block this positive decision for his creditors in Germany," the attorney said in a statement.
Job Tilmann, spokesman for the Frankfurt public prosecutors office, said he would not obstruct a transfer of funds to the creditors.
Schneider and his wife owe funds to about 50 banks, with the largest share owed to Deutsche Bank.

The couple fled Germany in 1994 after their real estate empire collapsed, leaving behind around five billion marks in debt. After a global man hunt, Schneider and his wife were found in Miami in 1995 and were returned to Germany in February this year.
Schneider is now in jail, awaiting his trial which should start around the end of the year. ($1=1.4846 Mark)
